ol.li: Learn the definition of eigenvector and eigenvalue.
Learn to find eigenvectors and eigenvalues geometrically.
Learn to decide if a number is an eigenvalue of a matrix, and if so, how to find an associated eigenvector.
Recipe: find a basis for the \lambda-eigenspace.
Pictures: whether or not a vector is an eigenvector, eigenvectors of standard matrix transformations.
Theorem: the expanded invertible matrix theorem.

introduction.p: In this section, we define eigenvalues and eigenvectors. These form the most important facet of the structure theory of square matrices. As such, eigenvalues and eigenvectors tend to play a key role in the real-life applications of linear algebra.

subsection.title: Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
subsection.p: Here is the most important definition in this text.

statement.p:
Let A be an n\times n matrix.
An eigenvector of A is a nonzero vector v in \R^n such that Av=\lambda v, for some scalar \lambda.
An eigenvalue of A is a scalar \lambda such that the equation Av=\lambda v has a nontrivial solution.
If Av = \lambda v for v\neq 0, we say that \lambda is the eigenvalue for v, and that v is an eigenvector for \lambda.

subsection.p: The German prefix eigen roughly translates to self or own. An eigenvector of A is a vector that is taken to a multiple of itself by the matrix transformation T(x)=Ax, which perhaps explains the terminology. On the other hand, eigen is often translated as characteristic; we may think of an eigenvector as describing an intrinsic, or characteristic, property of A.

note.p: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors are only for square matrices.

bluebox.p: Eigenvectors are by definition nonzero. Eigenvalues may be equal to zero.

subsection.p: We do not consider the zero vector to be an eigenvector: since A0 = 0 = \lambda 0 for every scalar \lambda, the associated eigenvalue would be undefined.

If someone hands you a matrix A and a vector v, it is easy to check if v is an eigenvector of A: simply multiply v by A and see if Av is a scalar multiple of v. On the other hand, given just the matrix A, it is not obvious at all how to find the eigenvectors. We will learn how to do this in .

statement.p:
Consider the matrix
A = \mat{2 2; -4 8} \sptxt{and vectors} v = \vec{1 1} \qquad w = \vec{2 1}.
Which are eigenvectors? What are their eigenvalues?

Consider the matrix
A = \mat{0 6 8; \frac 12 0 0; 0 \frac 12 0} \sptxt{and vectors} v = \vec{16 4 1} \qquad w = \vec{2 2 2}.
Which are eigenvectors? What are their eigenvalues?

solution.p:
We have
Av = \mat{0 6 8; \frac 12 0 0; 0 \frac 12 0}\vec{16 4 1} = \vec{32 8 2} = 2v.
Hence, v is an eigenvector of A, with eigenvalue \lambda = 2. On the other hand,
Aw = \mat{0 6 8; \frac 12 0 0; 0 \frac 12 0}\vec{2 2 2} = \vec{28 1 1},
which is not a scalar multiple of w. Hence, w is not an eigenvector of A.

statement.p:
Let
A = \mat{1 3; 2 6} \qquad v = \vec{-3 1}.
Is v an eigenvector of A? If so, what is its eigenvalue?

solution.p: The product is Av = \mat{1 3; 2 6}\vec{-3 1} = \vec{0 0} = 0v. Hence, v is an eigenvector with eigenvalue zero.
As noted above, an eigenvalue is allowed to be zero, but an eigenvector is not.

specialcase.title: Reflection
specialcase.p: Here is an example of this. Let T\colon\R^2\to\R^2 be the linear transformation that reflects over the line L defined by y=-x, and let A be the matrix for T. We will find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of A without doing any computations.
It appears that all eigenvectors lie either on L, or on the line perpendicular to L. The vectors on L have eigenvalue 1, and the vectors perpendicular to L have eigenvalue -1.

figure.caption: An eigenvector of A is a vector x such that Ax is collinear with x and the origin. Click and drag the head of x to convince yourself that all such vectors lie either on L, or on the line perpendicular to L.

statement.p: Let T\colon\R^2\to\R^2 be the linear transformation that projects a vector vertically onto the x-axis, and let A be the matrix for T. Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of A without doing any computations.

solution.p: It appears that all eigenvectors lie on the x-axis or the y-axis. The vectors on the x-axis have eigenvalue 1, and the vectors on the y-axis have eigenvalue 0.

figure.caption: An eigenvector of A is a vector x such that Ax is collinear with x and the origin. Click and drag the head of x to convince yourself that all such vectors lie on the coordinate axes.

statement.p: Find all eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the identity matrix I_n.

solution.p: The identity matrix has the property that I_nv = v for all vectors v in \R^n. We can write this as I_n v = 1\cdot v, so every nonzero vector is an eigenvector with eigenvalue 1.

figure.caption: Every nonzero vector is an eigenvector of the identity matrix.

figure.caption: Every nonzero vector is an eigenvector of a dilation matrix.
All eigenvectors of a shear lie on the x-axis. Click and drag the head of x to find the eigenvectors.

subsection.p: Here we mention one basic fact about eigenvectors.

fact.title: Eigenvectors with distinct eigenvalues are linearly independent

statement.p: Let v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k be eigenvectors of a matrix A, and suppose that the corresponding eigenvalues \lambda_1,\lambda_2,\ldots,\lambda_k are distinct (all different from each other). Then \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} is linearly independent.

proof.p: Suppose that \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} were linearly dependent. According to the increasing span criterion, this means that for some j, the vector v_j is in \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{j-1}\}. If we choose the first such j, then \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{j-1}\} is linearly independent. Note that j > 1 since v_1\neq 0.

Since v_j is in \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{j-1}\},, we can write v_j = c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 + \cdots + c_{j-1}v_{j-1} for some scalars c_1,c_2,\ldots,c_{j-1}. Multiplying both sides of the above equation by A gives
\begin{split} \lambda_jv_j = Av_j \amp= A\bigl(c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 + \cdots + c_{j-1}v_{j-1}\bigr) \\ \amp= c_1Av_1 + c_2Av_2 + \cdots + c_{j-1}Av_{j-1} \\ \amp= c_1\lambda_1v_1 + c_2\lambda_2v_2 + \cdots + c_{j-1}\lambda_{j-1}v_{j-1}. \end{split}
Subtracting \lambda_j times the first equation from the second gives
0 = \lambda_jv_j - \lambda_jv_j = c_1(\lambda_1-\lambda_j)v_1 + c_2(\lambda_2-\lambda_j)v_2 + \cdots + c_{j-1}(\lambda_{j-1}-\lambda_j)v_{j-1}.
Since \lambda_i\neq\lambda_j for i \lt j, this is an equation of linear dependence among v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{j-1}, which is impossible because those vectors are linearly independent. Therefore, \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_k\} must have been linearly independent after all.

subsection.p:
When k=2, this says that if v_1,v_2 are eigenvectors with eigenvalues \lambda_1\neq\lambda_2, then v_2 is not a multiple of v_1. In fact, any nonzero multiple cv_1 of v_1 is also an eigenvector with eigenvalue \lambda_1:
A(cv_1) = cAv_1 = c(\lambda_1 v_1) = \lambda_1(cv_1).
As a consequence of the above , we have the following.

bluebox.p: An n\times n matrix A has at most n eigenvalues.

subsection.title: Eigenspaces
subsection.p: Suppose that A is a square matrix. We already know how to check if a given vector is an eigenvector of A and in that case to find the eigenvalue. Our next goal is to check if a given real number is an eigenvalue of A and in that case to find all of the corresponding eigenvectors. Again this will be straightforward, but more involved. The only missing piece, then, will be to find the eigenvalues of A; this is the main content of .

statement.p: Let A be an n\times n matrix, and let \lambda be an eigenvalue of A. The \lambda-eigenspace of A is the solution set of (A-\lambda I_n)v=0, i.e., the subspace \Nul(A-\lambda I_n).

subsection.p: Eigenspaceis a subspace The \lambda-eigenspace is a subspace because it is the null space of a matrix, namely, the matrix A-\lambda I_n. This subspace consists of the zero vector and all eigenvectors of A with eigenvalue \lambda.

note.p: Since a nonzero subspace is infinite, every eigenvalue has infinitely many eigenvectors. (For example, multiplying an eigenvector by a nonzero scalar gives another eigenvector.) On the other hand, there can be at most n linearly independent eigenvectors of an n\times n matrix, since \R^n has dimension n.

statement.p: For each of the numbers \lambda = -2, 1, 3, decide if \lambda is an eigenvalue of the matrix A = \mat{2 -4; -1 -1}, and if so, compute a basis for the \lambda-eigenspace.

solution.p:
The number 3 is an eigenvalue of A if and only if \Nul(A-3I_2) is nonzero. Hence, we have to solve the matrix equation (A-3I_2)v = 0. We have
A - 3I_2 = \mat{2 -4; -1 -1} - 3\mat{1 0; 0 1} = \mat{-1 -4; -1 -4}.
The reduced row echelon form of this matrix is
\mat{1 4; 0 0} \quad\xrightarrow[\text{form}]{\text{parametric}}\quad \syseq{x = -4y; y = y} \quad\xrightarrow[\text{vector form}]{\text{parametric}}\quad \vec{x y} = y\vec{-4 1}.
Since y is a free variable, the null space of A-3I_2 is nonzero, so 3 is an eigenvector. A basis for the 3-eigenspace is \bigl\{{-4\choose 1}\bigr\}.

Concretely, we have shown that the eigenvectors of A with eigenvalue 3 are exactly the nonzero multiples of {-4\choose 1}. In particular, -4\choose 1 is an eigenvector, which we can verify:
\mat{2 -4; -1 -1}\vec{-4 1} = \vec{-12 3} = 3\vec{-4 1}.

The number 1 is an eigenvalue of A if and only if \Nul(A-I_2) is nonzero. Hence, we have to solve the matrix equation (A-I_2)v = 0. We have
A - I_2 = \mat{2 -4; -1 -1} - \mat{1 0; 0 1} = \mat{1 -4; -1 -2}.
This matrix has determinant -6, so it is invertible. By the , we have \Nul(A-I_2) = \{0\}, so 1 is not an eigenvalue.

The eigenvectors of A with eigenvalue -2, if any, are the nonzero solutions of the matrix equation (A+2I_2)v = 0. We have
A + 2I_2 = \mat{2 -4; -1 -1} + 2\mat{1 0; 0 1} = \mat{4 -4; -1 1}.
The reduced row echelon form of this matrix is
\mat{1 -1; 0 0} \quad\xrightarrow[\text{form}]{\text{parametric}}\quad \syseq{x = y; y = y} \quad\xrightarrow[\text{vector form}]{\text{parametric}}\quad \vec{x y} = y\vec{1 1}.
Hence there exist eigenvectors with eigenvalue -2, namely, any nonzero multiple of {1\choose 1}. A basis for the -2-eigenspace is \bigl\{{1\choose 1}\bigr\}.

figure.caption: The 3-eigenspace is the line spanned by {-4\choose 1}. This means that A scales every vector in that line by a factor of 3. Likewise, the -2-eigenspace is the line spanned by {1\choose 1}. Click and drag the vector x around to see how A acts on that vector.

statement.p: For each of the numbers \lambda=0, \frac 12, 2, decide if \lambda is an eigenvector of the matrix A = \mat{7/2 0 3; -3/2 2 -3; -3/2 0 -1}, and if so, compute a basis for the \lambda-eigenspace.

solution.p:
The number 2 is an eigenvalue of A if and only if \Nul(A-2I_3) is nonzero. Hence, we have to solve the matrix equation (A-2I_3)v = 0. We have
A - 2I_3 = \mat{7/2 0 3; -3/2 2 -3; -3/2 0 1} - 2\mat{1 0 0; 0 1 0; 0 0 1} = \mat{3/2 0 3; -3/2 0 -3; -3/2 0 -3}.
The reduced row echelon form of this matrix is
\mat{1 0 2; 0 0 0; 0 0 0} \quad\xrightarrow[\text{form}]{\text{parametric}}\quad \syseq{x = -2z; y = y; z = z} \quad\xrightarrow[\text{vector form}]{\text{parametric}}\quad \vec{x y z} = y\vec{0 1 0} + z\vec{-2 0 1}.
The matrix A-2I_3 has two free variables, so the null space of A-2I_3 is nonzero, and thus 2 is an eigenvector. A basis for the 2-eigenspace is \left\{\vec{0 1 0},\,\vec{-2 0 1}\right\}. This is a plane in \R^3.

The eigenvectors of A with eigenvalue \frac 12, if any, are the nonzero solutions of the matrix equation (A-\frac 12I_3)v = 0. We have
A - \frac 12I_3 = \mat{7/2 0 3; -3/2 2 -3; -3/2 0 1} - \frac 12\mat{1 0 0; 0 1 0; 0 0 1} = \mat{3 0 3; -3/2 3/2 -3; -3/2 0 -3/2}.
The reduced row echelon form of this matrix is
\mat{1 0 1; 0 1 -1; 0 0 0} \quad\xrightarrow[\text{form}]{\text{parametric}}\quad \syseq{x = -z; y = z; z = z} \quad\xrightarrow[\text{vector form}]{\text{parametric}}\quad \vec{x y z} = z\vec{-1 1 1}.
Hence there exist eigenvectors with eigenvalue \frac 12, so \frac 12 is an eigenvalue. A basis for the \frac 12-eigenspace is \left\{\vec{-1 1 1}\right\}. This is a line in \R^3.

The number 0 is an eigenvalue of A if and only if \Nul(A-0I_3) = \Nul(A) is nonzero. This is the same as asking whether A is noninvertible, by the . The determinant of A is \det(A) = 2\neq 0, so A is invertible by the invertibility property. It follows that 0 is not an eigenvalue of A.

figure.caption: The 2-eigenspace is the violet plane. This means that A scales every vector in that plane by a factor of 2. The \frac 12-eigenspace is the green line. Click and drag the vector x around to see how A acts on that vector.

statement.p: Let T\colon\R^2\to\R^2 be the linear transformation that reflects over the line L defined by y=-x, and let A be the matrix for T. Find all eigenspaces of A.

solution.p: We showed in this that all eigenvectors with eigenvalue 1 lie on L, and all eigenvectors with eigenvalue -1 lie on the line L^\perp that is perpendicular to L. Hence, L is the 1-eigenspace, and L^\perp is the -1-eigenspace.

None of this required any computations, but we can verify our conclusions using algebra. First we compute the matrix A:
T\vec{1 0} = \vec{0 -1} \qquad T\vec{0 1} = \vec{-1 0} \quad\implies\quad A = \mat{0 -1; -1 0}.
Computing the 1-eigenspace means solving the matrix equation (A-I_2)v=0. We have
A-I_2 = \mat{0 -1; -1 0} - \mat{1 0; 0 1} = \mat{-1 -1; -1 -1} \quad\xrightarrow{\text{RREF}}\quad\mat{1 1; 0 0}.
The parametric form of the solution set is x = -y, or equivalently, y = -x, which is exactly the equation for L. Computing the -1-eigenspace means solving the matrix equation (A+I_2)v=0; we have
A+I_2 = \mat{0 -1; -1 0} + \mat{1 0; 0 1} = \mat{1 -1; -1 1} \quad\xrightarrow{\text{RREF}}\quad\mat{1 -1; 0 0}.
The parametric form of the solution set is x = y, or equivalently, y = x, which is exactly the equation for L^\perp.

figure.caption: The violet line L is the 1-eigenspace, and the green line L^\perp is the -1-eigenspace.

bluebox.title: Recipes: Eigenspaces
bluebox.p:
Let A be an n\times n matrix and let \lambda be a number.
\lambda is an eigenvalue of A if and only if (A-\lambda I_n)v = 0 has a nontrivial solution, if and only if \Nul(A-\lambda I_n)\neq\{0\}.
In this case, finding a basis for the \lambda-eigenspace of A means finding a basis for \Nul(A-\lambda I_n), which can be done by finding the parametric vector form of the solutions of the homogeneous system of equations (A-\lambda I_n)v = 0.
The dimension of the \lambda-eigenspace of A is equal to the number of free variables in the system of equations (A-\lambda I_n)v = 0, which is the number of columns of A - \lambda I_n without pivots.
The eigenvectors with eigenvalue \lambda are the nonzero vectors in \Nul(A-\lambda I_n), or equivalently, the nontrivial solutions of (A-\lambda I_n)v = 0.

subsection.p: We conclude with an observation about the 0-eigenspace of a matrix.

statement.p:
Let A be an n\times n matrix.
The number 0 is an eigenvalue of A if and only if A is not invertible.
In this case, the 0-eigenspace of A is \Nul(A).

proof.p: We know that 0 is an eigenvalue of A if and only if \Nul(A - 0I_n) = \Nul(A) is nonzero, which is equivalent to the noninvertibility of A by the . In this case, the 0-eigenspace is by definition \Nul(A-0I_n) = \Nul(A).

subsection.p: Concretely, an eigenvector with eigenvalue 0 is a nonzero vector v such that Av=0v, i.e., such that Av = 0. These are exactly the nonzero vectors in the null space of A.

subsection.title: The Invertible Matrix Theorem: Addenda
subsection.p: We now have two new ways of saying that a matrix is invertible, so we add them to the invertible matrix theorem.

statement.p:
Let A be an n\times n matrix, and let T\colon\R^n\to\R^n be the matrix transformation T(x) = Ax. The following statements are equivalent:
A is invertible.
A has n pivots.
\Nul(A) = \{0\}.
The columns of A are linearly independent.
The columns of A span \R^n.
Ax=b has a unique solution for each b in \R^n.
T is invertible.
T is one-to-one.
T is onto.
\det(A) \neq 0.
0 is not an eigenvalue of A.
